newsitem.title: INDIA: Warring India leaders want talks but talk tough.
newsitem.headline: Warring India leaders want talks but talk tough.

text.p: India's Congress party and the ruling United Front alliance on Friday inched towards talks to end a political crisis started by Congress's withdrawal of vital support to the government.

The 15-party United Front coalition said it was willing to talk to its rival but refused to budge on a Congress demand that Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda should step down to make way for a Congress-led coalition.

The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), whose 12-day-old government fell last May when Congress and the United Front closed ranks, said it would decide on a strategy at a weekend meeting of the party's national executive committee.
Congress spokesman Vithal Gadgil told Reuters the party stood behind party president Sitaram Kesri, but added that talks with Deve Gowda's centre-left alliance were possible.
Asked whether Congress was ready for talks to end the crisis, Gadgil said: "Let the proposal come." Asked if the Congress was open for talks, he said: "Yes, yes."

Kesri withdrew the party's make-or-break support to the minority government headed by Deve Gowda on Sunday, citing economic drift and the government's weakness in containing Hindu nationalists in the opposition.
The 15-party United Front (UF), made up of centrists, regional groups and communists, is scheduled to face a vote of confidence in the lower house of parliament on April 11.
Politicians said hectic talks were on behind the scenes between middle-ranking Congress and United Front leaders to avoid premature elections after the last polls held a year ago.

Later on Friday, Gadgil told a news conference that Congress insisted on forming a new government. "The only solution to the present political solution is a Congress-led coalition at the centre (federal government)," he said.
United Front spokesman Jaipal Reddy said talks towards forming a joint body to iron out differences were possible, but that the coalition would not meet Congress's demand for power.
"A change in the leadership is non-negotiable," he said. "The question of supporting a Congress-led coalition does not arise at all."
The convenor of the United Front's decision-making Steering Committee, Chandrababu Naidu, might consider issuing an invitation for talks, Reddy said. Naidu was expected to reach Delhi on Sunday.
"There is absolutely no difficulty or hesitation in sending a formal invitation," Reddy said. "We are ready to discuss modalities for structured interaction."
On Thursday, the United Front snubbed a key demand from the Congress to replace Deve Gowda after Kesri said on Tuesday that the Congress would reconsider its position if he resigned.
"What is significant is that the Congress in the past few days has come to terms with reality," said analyst Mahesh Rangarajan of New Delhi's Centre for Contemporary Studies.

Deve Gowda could survive the trust vote only if Congress split or lawmakers in the main opposition Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party abstained. The government would need a simple majority of members present and voting.
The BJP and its allies control 193 votes in the 545-seat lower house. The United Front has 180 votes and Congress 140.
